Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) inhibits serum-dependent proliferation of the human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2. We have previously shown that HGF induces strong activation of ERK in HepG2 cells, and a reduction of this strong activation to a weak activation by a low concentration of MEK inhibitors restores the proliferation of HepG2 cells inhibited by HGF (5Tsukada Y. Miyazawa K. Kitamura N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40968-40976Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). These results indicate that the activation of ERK is required for both the stimulation and inhibition of HepG2 cell proliferation, and the level of ERK activation determines the opposing proliferation responses: the strong activation is required for the inhibition of proliferation, whereas the weak activation leads to the stimulation of proliferation. The strong activation of ERK by HGF changes the expression of regulators of the cell cycle including cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk) inhibitors, p16INK4a, p21CIP1, and p27KIP1, cyclin A, and E2F1 (6Tsukada Y. Tanaka T. Miyazawa K. Kitamura N. J. Biochem. 2004; 136: 701-709Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 7Han J. Tsukada Y. Hara E. Kitamura N. Tanaka T. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 31548-31556Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Detailed analysis of the expression of p16 revealed that the activated ERK pathway induces the activation of a member of the Ets family of transcription factors, which up-regulates the expression of p16. The p16 protein forms a complex with Cdk4, leading to the redistribution of p21 and p27 from Cdk4 to Cdk2. The association of p21 and p27 with Cdk2 represses Cdk2 activity, resulting in hypophosphorylation of pRb. The hypophosphorylated pRb eventually causes cell cycle arrest at G1 (6Tsukada Y. Tanaka T. Miyazawa K. Kitamura N. J. Biochem. 2004; 136: 701-709Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 7Han J. Tsukada Y. Hara E. Kitamura N. Tanaka T. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 31548-31556Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Thus, one crucial molecular pathway linking the strong activation of the ERK pathway to the HGF-induced cell cycle arrest in HepG2 cells is the up-regulation of p16 expression. The biological effects of HGF on the proliferation of cells are transduced through the activation of its high affinity receptor, the c-met proto-oncogene product (c-Met) (8Bottaro D.P. Rubin J.S. Faletto D.L. Chan A.M.-L. Kmiecik T.E. Vande Woude G.F. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1991; 251: 802-804Crossref PubMed Scopus (2085) Google Scholar, 9Naldini L. Weidner K.M. Vigna E. Gaudino G. Bardelli A. Ponzetto C. Narsimhan R.P. Hartmann G. Zarnegar R. Michalopoulos G.K. Birchmeier W. Comoglio P.M. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 2867-2878Crossref PubMed Scopus (589) Google Scholar, 10Komada M. Miyazawa K. Ishii T. Kitamura N. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 204: 857-864Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 11Weidner K.M. Sachs M. Birchmeier W. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 145-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). The association of HGF with c-Met elicits recruitment of the Grb2/Sos complex to the activated c-Met (12Ponzetto C. Bardelli A. Zhen Z. Mina F. Zonca P.D. Giordano S. Graziani A. Panayotou G. Comoglio P.M. Cell. 1994; 77: 261-271Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (893) Google Scholar). The translocation of Sos to the plasma membrane occurs close to Ras and can stimulate the exchange of GTP for GDP. The binding of GTP to Ras initiates a protein cascade, which leads to ERK activation through the intervening protein kinases Raf and MEK (13Schlessinger J. Cell. 2000; 103: 211-225Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3532) Google Scholar). Thus, the HGF-induced strong activation of ERK in HepG2 cells is a consequence of the up-regulation of one of these reactions. However, the mechanism of the up-regulation remains to be elucidated. Two mechanisms have been described for the association of Grb2 with c-Met, that is the initial event of the Ras/ERK pathway. One is direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met. The association of HGF with c-Met triggers phosphorylation of two C-terminal tyrosines (Tyr1349 and Tyr1356) essential for the c-Met signaling (12Ponzetto C. Bardelli A. Zhen Z. Mina F. Zonca P.D. Giordano S. Graziani A. Panayotou G. Comoglio P.M. Cell. 1994; 77: 261-271Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (893) Google Scholar). The phosphorylation of Tyr1356 is required for Grb2 to directly bind to c-Met. In addition, the asparagine residue (Asn1358) at position +2 of Tyr1356 is also essential for the binding of Grb2 to c-Met, because replacement of the asparagine with histidine impairs the binding (14Ponzetto C. Zhen Z. Audero E. Maina F. Bardelli A. Basile M.L. Giordano S. Narsimhan R. Comoglio P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 14119-14123Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 15Nguyen L. Holgado-Madruga M. Maroun C. Fixman E.D. Kamikura D. Fournier T. Charest A. Tremblay M.L. Wong A.J. Park M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20811-20819Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). The other mechanism of the association of Grb2 with c-Met is through the adaptor protein Shc (16Pelicci G. Giordano S. Zhen Z. Salcini A.E. Lanfrancone L. Bardelli A. Panayotou G. Waterfield M.D. Ponzetto C. Pelicci P.G. Comoglio P.M. Oncogene. 1995; 10: 1631-1638PubMed Google Scholar). Phosphorylation of Tyr1349 and Tyr1356 is involved in the binding of Shc to c-Met, but Asn1358 is not required for the binding (17Fournier T.M. Kamikura D. Teng K. Park M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 22211-22217Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Tyrosine phosphorylation of Shc at Tyr317 (YVNV) forms a consensus binding site for Grb2 (18Skolnik E.Y. Lee C.-H. Batzer A. Vicentini L.M. Zhou M. Daly R. Myers M.J.J. Backer J.M. Ullrich A. White M.F. Schlessinger J. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 1929-1936Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar), and the association of Grb2 with Shc promotes activation of Ras (19Rozakis-Adcock M. McGlade J. Mbamalu G. Pelicci G. Daly R. Li W. Batzer A. Thomas S. Brugge J. Pelicci P.G. Schlessinger J. Pawson T. Nature. 1992; 360: 689-692Crossref PubMed Scopus (827) Google Scholar). Shc has been shown to be tyrosine-phosphorylated in cells stimulated with HGF (16Pelicci G. Giordano S. Zhen Z. Salcini A.E. Lanfrancone L. Bardelli A. Panayotou G. Waterfield M.D. Ponzetto C. Pelicci P.G. Comoglio P.M. Oncogene. 1995; 10: 1631-1638PubMed Google Scholar). In this study, we examined which mechanism is involved in the HGF-induced strong activation of ERK, which is required for cell cycle arrest in HepG2 cells. To this end, we constructed a chimeric receptor composed of the extracellular ligand-binding domain of the NGF receptor and the cytoplasmic domain of c-Met, and introduced a point mutation into this chimeric receptor by replacing Asn1358 with His, which specifically abrogates the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met. We introduced this mutated receptor into HepG2 cells, and analyzed effects of the mutation on the ERK activation and cell proliferation. The results demonstrated that the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met is crucial for the HGF-induced strong activation of ERK, which leads to inhibition of cell proliferation. In addition to the translocation of Sos to the plasma membrane, the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met contributes to the association of the docking protein Gab1 with c-Met, which amplifies the Ras/ERK pathway through the tyrosine phosphatase Shp2 (20Schaeper U. Gehring N.H. Fuchs K.P. Sachs M. Kempkes B. Birchmeier W. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 149: 1419-1432Crossref PubMed Scopus (292) Google Scholar, 21Maroun C.R. Naujokas M.A. Holgado-Madruga M. Wong A.J. Park M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 8513-8525Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). Therefore, we further examined the involvement of Gab1 in the strong activation of ERK, using the RNAi method. The result demonstrated that Gab1 plays a crucial role in the strong activation of ERK, which is required for the HGF-induced inhibition of HepG2 cell proliferation. Reagents—Reagents were obtained as follows: anti-c-Met (sc161), anti-p16 (sc759), and anti-GST (sc459) antibodies from Santa Cruz Biotechnology; anti-trkA (06-574), anti-ERK2 (05-157), and anti-Gab1 (06-579) antibodies from Upstate Biotechnology; anti-phosphotyrosine antibody (PY20) from Transduction Laboratories; anti-α-tubulin antibody (T9026) from Sigma; antiphospho-p44/42 MAPK (Thr202/Tyr204) antibody (9106) from Cell Signaling Technology; horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse (NA931) and anti-rabbit (NA934) Ig from Amersham Biosciences; recombinant human HGF from the Research Center of Mitsubishi Chemical Corp.; and NGF from Alomone Labs. Construction of TrkA/c-Met Chimeric Receptor cDNA Expression Plasmid—The plasmid including rat TrkA cDNA (pRc/CMV-rat TrkA) was kindly provided by Dr. K. Suzuki of Novartis Pharm Corp. Human c-Met cDNA was amplified from RNA of HepG2 cells by RT-PCR, and cloned into pME18S. The TrkA cDNA was amplified by PCR using primer 1, 5′-ACACAAAAGCTTCAGGGCTC-3′, and primer 3, 5′-GCAATCAATCCTGTGAATTCGTCCTTCTTCTCC-3′. The c-Met cDNA was amplified using primer 2, 5′-GGAGAAGAAGGACGAATTCACAGGATTGATTGC-3′, and primer 4, 5′-GCTCGGTAGTCTACAGATTC-3′. The PCR products were mixed and used as templates for PCR with primers 1 and 4. The obtained chimeric fragment was digested with HindIII and AccI, and ligated to cDNA fragments encoding the extracellular region of TrkA and the intracellular region of c-Met. The full-length chimeric receptor cDNA was inserted into an expression plasmid pcDNA5/FRT. Point mutations were introduced with a QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene). Cell Culture—COS7 cells were cultured in DMEM containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 at 37 °C. HepG2 cells expressing chimeric receptors were cultured in the same medium further containing 120 μg/ml hygromycin B. Cell Lysate Preparation and Immunoprecipitation—Cells were washed twice with cold phosphate-buffered saline containing 1% EDTA and 0.2 mm Na3VO4. For the immunoblot analysis of ERK2, cells were lysed with lysis buffer (mobility shift) (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mm Na3Vo4, 50 mm NaF, and 30 mm tetrasodium pyrophosphate) containing 5 μg/ml leupeptin, 1 μg/ml pepstatin A, 2 μg/ml aprotinin, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. For the immunoblot analysis of other proteins, cells were lysed with lysis buffer (RIPA) (137 mm NaCl, 8.1 mm Na2HPO4·12H2O, 2.68 mm KCl, 14.7 mm KH2PO4, 2 mm Na3VO4, 5 mm EDTA, 1% Nonidet P-40, and 0.5% deoxycholic acid) containing the same protease inhibitors. The lysates were cleared by centrifugation, and the protein concentration in the lysate was determined using the BCA protein assay reagent (Pierce). Equal amounts of cell lysate were incubated with antibody for 2 h at 4 °C, and then with a 50% slurry of protein A-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences) for 1 h at 4 °C. The immune complexes were precipitated and washed twice with washing buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 159 mm NaCl, 2 mm Na3VO4, 0.1% Nonidet P-40, and 50 mm NaF). Immunoblot Analysis—The cell lysates and precipitated immune complexes were boiled in Laemmli sample buffer (62.5 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 2% SDS, 10% glycerol, 0.001% bromphenol blue, and 5% 2-mercaptoethanol). The samples were then separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes. The membranes were incubated with the primary antibody for 1 h at room temperature and then with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody for 1 h at room temperature. Immunoreactive proteins were visualized with an enhanced chemiluminescence Western blotting detection system (ECL, GE Healthcare). Assay for in Vitro Binding to Immobilized GST Fusion Proteins (GST Pull-down)—The full-length Grb2 cDNA was obtained by PCR using primers, 5′-GCGGATCCATGGAAGCCATCGCC-3′ and 5′-CGAATTCTTAGACGTTCCGGTTCAC-3′, and pME18S-HA-Grb2 (provided by Dr. M. Kato, Tokyo Institute of Technology) as a template. The PCR product was digested with BamHI and EcoRI and inserted into the BamHI and EcoRI sites of pGEX-6P-2 (Amersham Biosciences). The GST fusion protein was expressed in Escherichia coli XL1-blue. COS7 cells were transfected with expression vectors encoding chimeric receptors using FuGENE6 transfection reagent (Roche Applied Sciences). At 48 h after transfection, cells were treated with NGF (100 ng/ml) for 5 min, and then cell lysates were prepared. The cell lysate was incubated with purified GST-Grb2 bound to glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads for 1 h at 4 °C. After the beads were washed twice with lysis buffer, the binding proteins were released by boiling in 2× Laemmli sample buffer, and then separated by SDS-PAGE, before being analyzed by immunoblotting. Isolation of HepG2 Cell Clones Stably Expressing the Chimeric Receptors—The Flp-In™ System was obtained from Invitrogen. HepG2 cells were transfected with pFRT/LacZeo using FuGENE6 transfection reagent, and cultured for 48 h. The cells were then cultured in selective medium containing Zeocin (250 μg/ml). Cells resistant to Zeocin were selected and expanded. A cell clone was used as a Flp-In host cell clone. The host cell clone was cotransfected with the expression plasmids encoding the chimeric receptors and the Flp-expression plasmid pOG44 using JetPEI transfection reagent (Poly Transfection), and cultured for 48 h. The cells were then cultured in selective medium containing hygromycin B (350 μg/ml). SEAP Receptor Assay—Cells were seeded at a density of 1.25 × 105 cells/well in six-well plates. After 24 h, the medium was replaced with fresh medium, and plasmid pRRE (collagenase-1)-SEAP or pSRE (c-fos)-SEAP (2.2 μg) was transfected into the cells using FuGENE6 transfection reagent. At 24 h after transfection, the cells were treated with HGF (50 ng/ml) or NGF (100 ng/ml) for 48 h. The culture medium was harvested, and subjected to a SEAP assay. The SEAP assay was performed using a SEAP reporter assay kit (Toyobo), and chemiluminescence was quantified on a Wallac 1420 ARVOsx multi-label counter. Cell Proliferation Assay—Cells were seeded at a density of 5 × 104 cells/well in 12-well plates and cultured in DMEM containing 10% FBS. After 24 h, the medium was replaced with fresh medium containing 10% FBS, and the cells were treated with HGF (50 ng/ml) or NGF (100 ng/ml) for 4 days. The cells were harvested after trypsinization, and the number of cells was counted using a hemocytometer. RNA Interference—Using the small interfering RNA (siRNA) expression vector pSilencer 1.0-U6 (Ambion Inc.), vectors that target Gab1 mRNA were constructed. The Gab1 siRNA vectors siRNA-1 and 2 target the nucleotide residues at positions 165-183 in the coding region (5′-GCCTATTCGTATTATTGAT-3′) and 2206-2224 in the 3′ non-coding region (5′-AGGACCTTTCTGACATAAT-3′) from the translation initiation codon, respectively. DNA oligonucleotides containing the sense target sequence, a hairpin loop, and the antisense target sequence were synthesized, annealed, and inserted into pSilencer 1.0-U6. The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in 6-well plates and cultured with DMEM containing 10% FBS for 24 h. The medium was replaced with fresh medium, and cells were treated with 4 μg of the expression plasmid mixed with 11.2 μl of jetPEI for 24 h. The medium was replaced with fresh medium, and cells were treated again with 4 μg of the expression plasmid mixed with 11.2 μl of jetPEI for 48 h. The medium was replaced with fresh medium, and cells were further cultured in the absence and presence of HGF (50 ng/ml). Construction of Mutated Receptors—To distinguish transfected c-Met from the endogenous receptor in HepG2 cells, we constructed a cDNA encoding a chimeric receptor composed of the extracellular ligand-binding domain of the rat NGF receptor (TrkA), and the transmembrane and cytoplasmic domain of human c-Met, because NGF treatment did not affect the proliferation and morphology of HepG2 cells (data not shown), and the TrkA protein was not detected in HepG2 cells in an immunoblotting analysis (data not shown). To examine the requirement of the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met for the HGF-induced strong ERK activation and the inhibition of proliferation in HepG2 cells, we introduced a point mutation into this chimeric receptor by replacing the asparagine 1358 of human c-Met with a histidine residue (N1358H) by site-directed mutagenesis of the cDNA. This mutation has been shown to specifically abrogate the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met (14Ponzetto C. Zhen Z. Audero E. Maina F. Bardelli A. Basile M.L. Giordano S. Narsimhan R. Comoglio P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 14119-14123Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 15Nguyen L. Holgado-Madruga M. Maroun C. Fixman E.D. Kamikura D. Fournier T. Charest A. Tremblay M.L. Wong A.J. Park M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20811-20819Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). As a negative control for the tyrosine kinase activity of c-Met, we introduced a point mutation at the ATP binding site by replacing lysine 1110 with an alanine residue (K1110A). In addition, as a negative control for the signaling downstream from c-Met, we introduced point mutations at the multifunctional docking site of c-Met by replacing tyrosines 1349 and 1356 with phenylalanine residues (Y1349F/Y1356F). The cDNAs encoding the wild-type and mutated chimeric receptors were inserted into an expression vector, pcDNA5/FRT. The inability of Grb2 to bind to the mutated receptors was confirmed by the GST pull-down method (12Ponzetto C. Bardelli A. Zhen Z. Mina F. Zonca P.D. Giordano S. Graziani A. Panayotou G. Comoglio P.M. Cell. 1994; 77: 261-271Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (893) Google Scholar). The wild-type and mutated chimeric receptors were transiently expressed in COS7 cells, and the cells were treated with NGF. The expressed receptors were assayed for binding to the GST-fused Grb2. The wild-type receptor bound to GST-Grb2, whereas the mutated receptors did not (Fig. 1). Isolation of HepG2 Cell Clones Stably Expressing the Chimeric Receptors—To obtain HepG2 cell clones equally expressing each receptor, the Flp-In System was used. The plasmid pFRT/lacZeo was transfected into HepG2 cells. Cell clones resistant to Zeocin were selected and expanded. A cell clone, which showed HGF-induced inhibition of proliferation and scattering similarly to parental HepG2 cells, was selected and used as a Flp-In host cell line. The expression plasmids encoding the wild-type or mutated receptors were cotransfected with the Flp-expression plasmid pOG44 into the host cell line. Cell clones resistant to hygromycin B were selected and expanded. They were subjected to an analysis of the expression of receptor proteins by immunoblotting. Two clones for the wild-type and each mutated receptor were selected for further analysis. Receptor proteins were highly expressed in all clones (Fig. 2). To examine the tyrosine phosphorylation status of the receptors, each cell clone was left untreated or treated with HGF or NGF, and phosphorylation was analyzed by immunoprecipitation with an anti-c-Met antibody followed by immunoblotting with an anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. The phosphorylation was undetectable in untreated cells expressing the wild-type and mutated receptors. The phosphorylation of endogenous c-Met was detected in all cell clones treated with HGF. NGF treatment phosphorylated the wild-type, N1358H, and Y1349F/Y1356F receptors, but not the K1110A receptor (Fig. 2). These results indicate that the tyrosine kinase of the wild-type, N1358H, and Y1349F/Y1356F chimeric receptors was activated by ligand treatment. Failure of ERK Activation in HepG2 Cells Expressing the N1358H Receptor—ERK activity in HepG2 cells expressing the mutated receptors after ligand treatment was examined using two assay systems. First, the activity was assayed based on the phosphorylation of ERK2, which was detected by a mobility shift of phosphorylated ERK2 in an immunoblot analysis using an anti-ERK2 antibody. The phosphorylation of ERK2 was enhanced in HepG2 cells expressing the wild-type and mutated chimeric receptors after HGF treatment (Fig. 3), indicating that the signaling pathway linking c-Met to ERK was intact in all cell clones. NGF treatment enhanced the phosphorylation of ERK2 in cells expressing the wild-type receptor, but not in cells expressing mutated receptors (Fig. 3). Second, transcription activation controlled by the RRE of the collagenase-1 promoter and the SRE of the c-fos promoter, which are mediated by ERK (22Fafeur V. Tulasne D. Queva C. Vercamer C. Dimster V. Mattot V. Stehelin D. Desbiens X. Vandenbunder B. Cell Growth Differ. 1997; 8: 655-665PubMed Google Scholar, 23Wasylyk B. Hagman J. Gutierrez-Hartmann A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1998; 23: 213-216Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (446) Google Scholar, 24Graves B.J. Petersen J.M. Adv. Cancer Res. 1998; 75: 1-55Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), was analyzed. We previously made constructs that contained the SEAP reporter gene under the control of RRE (collagenase-1) or SRE (c-fos) (5Tsukada Y. Miyazawa K. Kitamura N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40968-40976Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). We used these constructs in the present study. Transcriptional activity controlled by RRE (collagenase-1) and SRE (c-fos) was enhanced in all cell clones treated with HGF. NGF treatment also enhanced the transcriptional activity in cells expressing the wild-type receptor, but not in cells expressing the mutated receptors (Fig. 4). These results suggest that the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met is required for the strong activation of the ERK pathway.FIGURE 4ERK-mediated transcriptional activation in HepG2 cells expressing the chimeric receptors. Cells were transiently transfected with the plasmid pRRE-SEAP or pSRE-SEAP. At 24 h after transfection, the cells were treated with or without HGF (50 ng/ml) or NGF (100 ng/ml) for 48 h. The SEAP assay was performed as described under “Experimental Procedures.” The average fold-increase compared with untreated cells is indicated. Each value represents the mean ± S.D. of triplicate determinations from a representative experiment.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) No Up-regulation of p16 Expression in HepG2 Cells Expressing the N1358H Receptor—We previously demonstrated that the expression of p16INK4a, a Cdk inhibitor, was enhanced in HepG2 cells treated with HGF, and the enhancement is mediated by the strong activation of ERK (7Han J. Tsukada Y. Hara E. Kitamura N. Tanaka T. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 31548-31556Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). We also demonstrated that the enhancement of p16 expression plays a crucial role in the HGF-induced inhibition of the proliferation of HepG2 cells (7Han J. Tsukada Y. Hara E. Kitamura N. Tanaka T. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 31548-31556Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Thus, the p16 gene is an important target gene downstream of the strong activation of the ERK pathway. The expression level of p16 was analyzed by immunoblotting using an anti-p16 antibody. The expression of p16 protein was enhanced in all cell clones treated with HGF. NGF treatment enhanced the p16 expression in cells expressing the wild-type receptor, but not in cells expressing the mutated receptors (Fig. 5). These results suggest that the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met is required for the up-regulation of an important target gene downstream of the ERK pathway in HGF-treated HepG2 cells. Requirement of Direct Binding of Grb2 to c-Met for the HGF-induced Inhibition of Proliferation and Scattering of HepG2 Cells—We have previously shown that HGF induced strong activation of ERK in HepG2 cells, and its reduction restored the proliferation of HepG2 cells inhibited by HGF (5Tsukada Y. Miyazawa K. Kitamura N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40968-40976Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Thus, it was assumed that the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met is required for the HGF-induced inhibition of the proliferation of HepG2 cells, because a failure of the binding did not enhance the activation of ERK and the expression of p16. The proliferation of HepG2 cells expressing the chimeric receptors after ligand treatment was tested by counting cell numbers. Proliferation was inhibited in HepG2 cells expressing the wild-type and mutated chimeric receptors after HGF treatment (Fig. 6). NGF treatment inhibited the proliferation of cells expressing the wild-type receptor. In contrast, proliferation was not inhibited among cells expressing the mutated receptors (Fig. 6). These results suggest that the direct binding of Grb2 to c-Met is required for the HGF-induced inhibition of proliferation of HepG2 cells. In addition to affecting proliferation, HGF induces scattering of cell colonies in HepG2 cells (5Tsukada Y. Miyazawa K. Kitamura N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40968-40976Ab

The cell surface of African trypanosomes is covered by a densely packed monolayer of a single protein, the variant surface glycoprotein (VSG). The VSG protects the trypanosome cell surface from effector molecules of the host immune system and is the mediator of antigenic variation. The sequence divergence between VSGs that is necessary for antigenic variation can only occur within the constraints imposed by the structural features necessary to form the monolayer barrier. Here, the structures of the two domains that together comprise the C-terminal di-domain of VSG ILTat1.24 have been determined. The first domain has a structure similar to the single C-terminal domain of VSG MITat1.2 and provides proof of structural conservation in VSG C-terminal domains complementing the conservation of structure present in the N-terminal domain. The second domain, although based on the same fold, is a minimized version missing several structural features. The structure of the second domain contains the C-terminal residue that in the native VSG is attached to a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor that retains the VSG on the external face of the plasma membrane. The solution structures of this domain and a VSG GPI glycan have been combined to produce the first structure-based model of a GPI-anchored protein. The model suggests that the core glycan of the GPI anchor lies in a groove on the surface of the domain and that there is a close association between the GPI glycan and protein. More widely, the GPI glycan may be an integral part of the structure of other GPI-anchored proteins. The cell surface of African trypanosomes is covered by a densely packed monolayer of a single protein, the variant surface glycoprotein (VSG). The VSG protects the trypanosome cell surface from effector molecules of the host immune system and is the mediator of antigenic variation. The sequence divergence between VSGs that is necessary for antigenic variation can only occur within the constraints imposed by the structural features necessary to form the monolayer barrier. Here, the structures of the two domains that together comprise the C-terminal di-domain of VSG ILTat1.24 have been determined. The first domain has a structure similar to the single C-terminal domain of VSG MITat1.2 and provides proof of structural conservation in VSG C-terminal domains complementing the conservation of structure present in the N-terminal domain. The second domain, although based on the same fold, is a minimized version missing several structural features. The structure of the second domain contains the C-terminal residue that in the native VSG is attached to a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor that retains the VSG on the external face of the plasma membrane. The solution structures of this domain and a VSG GPI glycan have been combined to produce the first structure-based model of a GPI-anchored protein. The model suggests that the core glycan of the GPI anchor lies in a groove on the surface of the domain and that there is a close association between the GPI glycan and protein. More widely, the GPI glycan may be an integral part of the structure of other GPI-anchored proteins. African trypanosomes, such as Trypanosoma brucei, proliferate in the bloodstream of mammals and can infect a host for years despite continual exposure to its immune system. Trypanosomes are susceptible to immunoglobulin-mediated complement lysis and have evolved a population survival strategy dependent on the appearance of antigenically novel variants at a rate sufficient to keep ahead of the immunoglobulin response of the host. Antigenic variation in trypanosomes (reviewed in Ref. 1Barry D. Carrington M. Maudlin I. Holmes P.H. Miles M.A. The Trypanosomiases. CABI Publishing, Oxford2004: 25-38Google Scholar) is based on the sequence diversity of members of the variant surface glycoprotein (VSG) 4The abbreviations used are: VSGvariant surface glycoproteinNOEnuclear Overhauser effectCOSYcorrelation spectroscopyTOCSYtotal correlation spectroscopyNOESYNOE spectroscopyHPLChigh performance liquid chromatographyGPIglycosylphosphatidylinositol. gene family, and during the course of an infection, the trypanosome population expresses a series of antigenically distinct VSGs. In an individual trypanosome, one VSG gene is expressed at any one time from a genomic reservoir of hundreds or thousands. The probability of any one trypanosome switching the expressed VSG gene to one encoding an antigenically novel VSG is low, and thus most trypanosomes do not switch VSGs and are cleared by the immune system of the host. Trypanosomes that do switch to an antigenically novel VSG undergo clonal proliferation until the immunoglobulin response against the new VSG imposes another round of selection for further novel antigenic variants. variant surface glycoprotein nuclear Overhauser effect correlation spectroscopy total correlation spectroscopy NOE spectroscopy high performance liquid chromatography glycosylphosphatidylinositol. In addition to its role in the population survival strategy, the VSG is also central to processes that have evolved to protect and prolong the life of individual trypanosomes. The cell surface VSG prevents other, invariant, cell surface proteins from triggering immunoglobulin-mediated complement attack. It forms a very densely packed monolayer on the cell surface (2Jackson D.G. Owen M.J. Voorheis H.P. Biochem. J. 1985; 230: 195-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 3Mehlert A. Bond C.S. Ferguson M.A.J. Glycobiology. 2002; 12: 607-612Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar), and either the density of VSG packing is sufficient to physically block antibodies binding other cell surface proteins, or the cell has another unknown mechanism to negate binding of antibodies to non-VSG proteins (4Ziegelbauer K. Overath P. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 4540-4545Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, the cell surface VSG monolayer is internalized to the endosome and recycled at a high rate; the entire cell surface pool of VSG can be internalized within 12 min (5Engstler M. Thilo L. Weise F. Grunfelder C.G. Schwarz H. Boshart M. Overath P. J. Cell Sci. 2004; 117: 1105-1115Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). While the VSG is in an unidentified part of the endosome, any bound immunoglobulin is degraded before the VSG is recycled to the cell surface (6O'Beirne C. Lowry C.M. Voorheis H.P. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1998; 91: 165-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 7Pal A. Hall B.S. Jeffries T.R. Field M.C. Biochem. J. 2003; 374: 443-451Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). Thus, the trypanosome is able to tolerate moderately high titers of anti-VSG immunoglobulin, and this probably allows individual cells to survive during the rising host immunoglobulin response, therefore increasing the chance of transmission to the insect vector. There are two apparently conflicting selection pressures on the VSG: diversity for antigenic variation and conservation of structure for formation of an effective cell surface barrier and features necessary for rapid internalization and recycling. The sequence diversity is extreme, with VSGs having 15-25% identity with most other VSGs. However, this sequence diversity is accommodated within a conserved structure (8Blum M.L. Down J.A. Gurnett A.M. Carrington M. Turner M.J. Wiley D. Nature. 1993; 362: 603-609Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar), although it remains unclear which structural features are necessary for protection and/or VSG recycling. VSGs are homodimers attached to the external face of the plasma membrane via a C-terminal glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor (9Ferguson M.A.J. Homans S.W. Dwek R.A. Rademacher T.W. Science. 1988; 239: 753-759Crossref PubMed Scopus (559) Google Scholar). VSGs of T. brucei and the closely related species Trypanosoma evansi are composed of an N-terminal domain of 350-400 residues and one or two C-terminal domains of 50-100 residues in total (10Carrington M. Miller N. Blum M. Roditi I. Wiley D. Turner M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 823-835Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). Attempts made to solve the structure of a complete VSG have been unsuccessful (11Garman, S. C. (1994) The X-ray Crystallographic Analysis of an Intact VSG from the Trypanosome. Ph. D. thesis, Harvard UniversityGoogle Scholar), but progress has been made with the individual domains (8Blum M.L. Down J.A. Gurnett A.M. Carrington M. Turner M.J. Wiley D. Nature. 1993; 362: 603-609Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 12Freymann D. Down G. Carrington M. Roditi I. Turner M.J. Wiley D.C. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 216: 141-160Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 13Chattopadhyay A. Jones N. Nietlispach D. Nielsen P. Voorheis H. Mott H. Carrington M. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 7227-7235Google Scholar). There are three types of N-terminal domains (A, B and C) based on the number and distribution of conserved cysteine residues (10Carrington M. Miller N. Blum M. Roditi I. Wiley D. Turner M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 823-835Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). The structures of two N-terminal domains, those of VSGs MITat1.2 and ILTat1.24, have been solved by x-ray crystallography (8Blum M.L. Down J.A. Gurnett A.M. Carrington M. Turner M.J. Wiley D. Nature. 1993; 362: 603-609Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 12Freymann D. Down G. Carrington M. Roditi I. Turner M.J. Wiley D.C. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 216: 141-160Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) and demonstrate a conserved tertiary structure between VSGs despite having only 16% sequence identity. It is likely that all type A VSG N-terminal domains have similar tertiary structures because they share common sequence features including conserved cysteine residues and heptad repeats that form a large coiled coil, which is the core of the structure (8Blum M.L. Down J.A. Gurnett A.M. Carrington M. Turner M.J. Wiley D. Nature. 1993; 362: 603-609Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar). Disulfide mapping experiments on type B N-terminal domains have provided experimental evidence that these, too, can adopt the same tertiary structure (14Bussler H. Linder M. Linder D. Reinwald E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 32582-32586Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). VSG C-terminal domains have been divided into six types (types 1-6) based on conserved cysteine residues, N-linked glycosylation sites, C-terminal residue, and GPI anchor signal sequence (10Carrington M. Miller N. Blum M. Roditi I. Wiley D. Turner M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 823-835Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 15Berriman M. Ghedin E. Hertz-Fowler C. Blandin G. Renauld H. Bartholomeu D.C. Lennard N.J. Caler E. Hamlin N.E. Haas B. Bohme U. Hannick L. Aslett M.A. Shallom J. Marcello L. Hou L. Wickstead B. Alsmark U.C. Arrowsmith C. Atkin R.J. Barron A.J. Bringaud F. Brooks K. Carrington M. Cherevach I. Chillingworth T.J. Churcher C. Clark L.N. Corton C.H. Cronin A. Davies R.M. Doggett J. Djikeng A. Feldblyum T. Field M.C. Fraser A. Goodhead I. Hance Z. Harper D. Harris B.R. Hauser H. Hostetler J. Ivens A. Jagels K. Johnson D. Johnson J. Jones K. Kerhornou A.X. Koo H. Larke N. Landfear S. Larkin C. Leech V. Line A. Lord A. Macleod A. Mooney P.J. Moule S. Martin D.M. Morgan G.W. Mungall K. Norbertczak H. Ormond D. Pai G. Peacock C.S. Peterson J. Quail M.A. Rabbinowitsch E. Rajandream M.A. Reitter C. Salzberg S.L. Sanders M. Schobel S. Sharp S. Simmonds M. Simpson A.J. Tallon L. Turner C.M. Tait A. Tivey A.R. Van Aken S. Walker D. Wanless D. Wang S. White B. White O. Whitehead S. Woodward J. Wortman J. Adams M.D. Embley T.M. Gull K. Ullu E. Barry J.D. Fairlamb A.H. Opperdoes F. Barrell B.G. Donelson J.E. Hall N. Fraser C.M. Melville S.E. El-Sayed N.M. Science. 2005; 309: 416-422Crossref PubMed Scopus (1335) Google Scholar). VSG C-terminal types 2, 4, and 5 are single domains containing four conserved cysteine residues, whereas types 1, 3, and 6 are di-domains, in which each subdomain contains four conserved cysteines. The structure of a type 2 VSG C-terminal domain, that from VSG MITat1.2, has been solved (13Chattopadhyay A. Jones N. Nietlispach D. Nielsen P. Voorheis H. Mott H. Carrington M. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 7227-7235Google Scholar). Although the structures of both domains of VSG MITat1.2 are now known, there remain 16 unstructured residues between the two domains and 17 unstructured residues between the C-terminal domain and the GPI anchor at the C terminus. Thus, the spatial relationship between the two domains and any interaction between the VSG and its GPI anchor remains uncharacterized. The next goal of research into understanding how the VSG functions is a complete structure-based model of the VSG monolayer. Current models (3Mehlert A. Bond C.S. Ferguson M.A.J. Glycobiology. 2002; 12: 607-612Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) are based on the known structure of the N-terminal domain alone and are therefore incomplete. Here, a step toward this goal is reported: the solution structures of the two domains that make up the type 1 VSG C terminus from ILTat1.24. The first domain has a structure very similar to that of the type 2 C-terminal domain, indicating that there is structural conservation between type 1 and 2 C-terminal domains. The second domain has a similar fold but is a smaller, apparently minimal, version and is missing some of the structural features found in the other two VSG C-terminal domains. Unlike the previously determined C-terminal domain structure, the second domain contains the mature C-terminal residue that is attached to the GPI anchor in the native protein, and this has allowed the modeling of the GPI-anchored domain based on the solution structures of this VSG domain and the GPI glycan. The result is the first fully structure-based model of any protein domain and its GPI anchor. The model suggests an interaction of the GPI glycan along the length of one side of the domain. Protein Expression and PurificationThree recombinant polypeptides were produced encoding different regions of the C-terminal part of ILTat1.24 (see Fig. 1). The expression constructs were based on pET15b (Novagen) and encoded polypeptides with a N-terminal sequence MGSSHHHHHHSSGLVPRGSHMLEENLYFQG followed by residues Glu368-Asp468 (I1.24C), Lys383-Ser427 (I1.24C1), or Thr422-Asp468 (I1.24C2) of the mature VSG ILTat1.24 (EMBL X56767). The tobacco etch virus protease site is underlined above. The polypeptides were expressed in Escherichia coli BL21trxB(DE3) grown in 2× TY medium. The recombinant C-terminal domains were isolated from the cell lysate by affinity chromatography on a Ni2+ column and removed from the tag by tobacco etch virus protease digestion. This resulted in an additional glycine residue at the N terminus of both I1.24C and I1.24C2, whereas this addition coincides with the presence of that residue (Gly382) in the mature VSG for I1.24C1. As a final purification step the proteins were subjected to reverse phase HPLC using a 25 × 1-cm Hichrom-5 C8 column in an acetonitrile gradient in the presence of 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid. The eluted protein was then concentrated in a SpeedVac to remove the majority of acetonitrile and trifluoroacetic acid, before buffer exchanging over Sephadex G25 (PD-10 column; Amersham Biosciences) into a buffer containing 50 mm sodium phosphate, 150 mm sodium chloride, pH 6.0. The relative molecular masses of the three polypeptides were determined using electrospray ion trap mass spectrometry by the University of Cambridge Department of Chemistry Mass Spectrometry Facility. Disulfide Isomerization of I1.24CA 0.5 mg/ml solution of I1.24C in 0.2 m Tris-HCl, 1 mm EDTA, 6 m guanidinium chloride, and 50 mm dithiothreitol, pH 8.0, was incubated at room temperature for 2 h to reduce disulfide bonds. The completely reduced protein was then exchanged into reshuffling buffer containing 0.2 m Tris-HCl, 1 mm EDTA, 0.25 mm oxidized glutathione, and 2.5 mm reduced glutathione, pH 8.5, at a protein concentration of 0.2 mg/ml. The reshuffling reaction was incubated at 35 °C for 3 h, after which the reaction was stopped by exchanging into 50 mm sodium phosphate, 150 mm NaCl, pH 6.0. NMR SpectroscopyNMR samples were composed of 0.5 mm I1.24C1 or I1.24C2 or of 0.3 mm I1.24C in 50 mm sodium phosphate, 150 mm sodium chloride, pH 6.0, and 10% D2O. The spectra were acquired at 25 °C on Bruker DRX500 (I1.24C2), Bruker DRX600 (I1.24C), and Bruker DRX800 (I1.24C1) spectrometers. 1H DQF-COSY, 1H TOCSY (72-ms DIPSI-2 mixing time), and 1H NOESY (150- and 200-ms mixing time for I1.24C1 and I1.24C2, respectively) were recorded on I1.24C1 and I1.24C2. A 1H NOESY (170-ms mixing time) was recorded on I1.24C. The spectra were processed using AZARA (W. Boucher, University of Cambridge) and analyzed using ANSIG (16Kraulis P.J. Domaile P.J. Campbell-Burk S.L. Van Aken T.V. Laue E.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 868-878Crossref Scopus (290) Google Scholar). Structure CalculationsStructure calculations were carried out using ARIA1.2 (17Linge J.P. O'Donoghue S.J. Nilges M. Methods Enzymol. 2001; 339: 71-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (333) Google Scholar) interfaced to CNS1.0 (18Brunger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. Celano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16979) Google Scholar). The structures were calculated with 90 ps of high temperature dynamics and 30 ps of cooling from 10,000 to 1,000 K in torsion angle space. This was followed by 24 ps of cooling from 1,000 to 50 K using dynamics in Cartesian space. Figures of structures were produced with Molscript (19Kraulis P.J. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 1991; 24: 627-633Crossref Google Scholar) and Raster3d (20Merritt E.A. Bacon D.J. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 277: 505-524Crossref PubMed Scopus (3878) Google Scholar). Docking the GPI Anchor and C2 DomainThe NMR structure closest to the mean of the ensemble was selected for both I1.24C2 and the VSG GPI glycan (21Homans S.W. Edge C.J. Ferguson M.A.J. Dwek R.A. Rademacher T.W. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 2881-2887Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar). Visual inspection of the properties of the surface-exposed charges was used to identify a possible binding site. Manual docking of the GPI anchor was performed, guided to reduce atomic clashes, and maximize potential electrostatic interactions. An amide bond was manually formed between the C-terminal aspartic acid residue (Asp468) of the protein and the exposed ethanolamine group of the GPI anchor using the Sybyl suite of programs (Tripos Inc., St. Louis, MO). The resulting glycoprotein structure was subjected to 100 iterations of energy minimization using the Tripos force field and Gasteiger-Marsili partial charges (22Gasteiger J. Marsili M. Org. Magn. Reson. 1981; 15: 353-360Crossref Scopus (108) Google Scholar). The figures were produced using Pymol (DeLano, W. L., The PyMOL Molecular Graphics System (2002) DeLano Scientific, San Carlos, CA). T. evansi VSGsT. evansi field isolates were collected from a domesticated deer (Cervus timorensis) and buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) in the Selangor province of Malaysia. The isolates were passaged four or five times through mice, a statutory requirement prior to import into the UK. RNA was prepared using RNAeasy kits (Qiagen), and VSG cDNA was prepared by reverse transcription-PCR as previously described (10Carrington M. Miller N. Blum M. Roditi I. Wiley D. Turner M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 823-835Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). The PCR product was cloned into pGEM-T, and three independent plasmids were sequenced for each VSG. Protein Expression and PurificationThe construct I1.24C (Fig. 1) encoded residues Glu368-Asp468 of VSG ILTat1.24 and was designed to determine the structure of the C-terminal di-domain. Each of the two domains contains four cysteines that are disulfide-bonded in the native VSG. Expression in three different E. coli trxB mutants, used to favor disulfide bond formation, and subsequent purification yielded protein that, although homogeneous by SDS-PAGE under reducing conditions, was heterogeneous under nonreducing conditions (data not shown). The pattern of bands under nonreducing conditions suggested that there was a mixture of different intramolecular disulfide-bonded and partially reduced forms of the protein. It was not possible to purify a single isoform from the mixture, and therefore the approach taken was to express the two domains separately. Expression of the individual domains, I1.24C1 and I1.24C2 (Fig. 1), also yielded proteins that were homogeneous using reducing SDS-PAGE and heterogeneous using nonreducing SDS-PAGE. For both I1.24C1 and I1.24C2, the slowest migrating monomeric form (nonreducing SDS-PAGE) was readily purified by reverse phase HPLC. Preliminary one-dimensional 1H NMR experiments showed that for both domains the slowest migrating form was structured, whereas the more rapidly migrating forms were not (data not shown). The purified polypeptides were analyzed by mass spectrometry to confirm identity and disulfide status. I1.24C1 had an average mass of 5124.8 g/mol, close to the expected mass of 5125.7 g/mol for the disulfide-bonded form. The second subdomain, I1.24C2, had an average mass of 4915.26 g/mol, close to the expected mass of 4915.4 g/mol for the disulfide-bonded form. Solution Structure of ILTat1.24C1I1.24C1 1H resonances were assigned using two-dimensional 1H COSY, 1H TOCSY, and 1H NOESY experiments. Full assignments were made for residues Ser384-Ser427. The NOESY yielded 946 unambiguous and 706 ambiguous NOEs. At the end of the eighth iteration of structure calculation, there were 192 ambiguous and 786 unambiguous distance restraints. In the last iteration, 100 structures were calculated, and the 35 with the lowest energy were used for further analyses. The core structure begins at Pro385, the fourth residue in the construct, and ends at Phe419, adjacent to an N-linked glycosylation site in the native VSG (Figs. 1 and 2A and Table 1). There are two α-helices comprising residues Pro385-Ile392 and Glu395-Glu400, which are connected by a tight turn, followed by another turn leading to two short β-strands comprising residues Cys404-Trp406 and Cys417-Phe419 that form an antiparallel β-sheet. The β-strands are connected by a long, 12-residue loop, and there are two hydrophobic residues, one located at the end of each β-strand (Trp406 and Phe419) that flank the disulfide bonds. A strong NOE was identified between the Hβ of Cys389 and Cys404, the first (CysI) and third (CysIII) cysteines in the domain, so these residues are likely to be linked by a disulfide bond. Because mass spectrometry analysis showed that there were no free sulfydryl groups present, the second (CysII) and fourth (CysIV) cysteines must also be disulfide-bonded, so the disulfide-bonding pattern in this domain is CysI-III and CysII-IV. This is the same disulfide-bonding pattern as has been shown previously for two other VSG C-terminal domains, those of MITat1.2 and MITat1.4 (13Chattopadhyay A. Jones N. Nietlispach D. Nielsen P. Voorheis H. Mott H. Carrington M. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 7227-7235Google Scholar, 23Allen G. Gurnett L.P. Biochem. Open table in a new tab Solution Structure of ILTat1.24C2I1.24C2 1H resonances were assigned using two-dimensional 1H COSY, 1H TOCSY, and 1H NOESY experiments. Full assignments were made for residues Ser425-Asp468. NOESY assignment yielded 613 unambiguous and 452 ambiguous NOEs. After eight iterations of structure calculation, there were 586 unambiguous and 42 ambiguous distance restraints. 100 structures were calculated in the final iteration, and the 35 lowest energy structures were used for further analyses. The core structure of the type 1 C2 domain of VSG ILTat1.24 has common features with the C1 domain, but some elements of the structure are absent, and the C2 domain is smaller with a core of just 25 residues, from Glu444-Asp468. Asp468 is the C terminus of the mature VSG, to which the GPI anchor is attached (Fig. 3 and Table 1). The secondary structure of this domain begins with residues Glu444%Lys449, which are not well defined but resemble a short bent α-helix followed by one turn of a 310-helix between residues Glu451 and Asp453 and another turn of a 310-helix between residues Ser456 and Asp458. This is immediately followed by an antiparallel β-sheet, formed by residues Lys460-Glu462 and Thr465-Lys467. The first β-strand contains a hydrophobic residue (Trp461) that caps the disulfide bonds on one side. Hβ NOEs were observed between Cys446 (CysI) and Cys459 (CysIII) and between Cys454 (CysII) and Cys466 (CysIV), confirming the pattern of disulfide bond formation as CysI-III and CysII-IV. A single NOE between one Hβ of Cys446 and one of Cys466 was identified, highlighting the close proximity of all four cysteines in the compact core structure. The I1.24C Di-DomainAfter the structures of the two individual subdomains had been determined, a procedure was developed for the successful reduction and reoxidization of the four disulfide bonds in I1.24C, the recombinant C-terminal di-domain. The product of the protocol was homogeneous on nonreducing SDS-PAGE and had a monoisotopic molecular mass of 11034.22 g/mol, very close to the expected mass of 11034.19 g/mol. An overlay of the NOESY spectrum of this di-domain with the NOESY spectra of the C1 and C2 domains showed that there were no significant changes in chemical shifts in the C2 subdomain resonances between the I1.24C2 and I1.24C polypeptides (data not shown). Slight changes in some backbone amide chemical shifts were observed for resonances in the C1 subdomain, but these could be attributed to small changes in the sample conditions. No NOEs were observed between the two subdomains, and there was no indication of additional secondary structural elements in the NOESY spectrum of I1.24C. The similarity of the spectra provides strong evidence that the structures of the isolated domains are repeated in the di-domain and that there is no interaction between the domains in the recombinant polypeptide. In the native VSG there is an N-linked glycosylation site in the linker between the C1 and C2 domains that is occupied by an oligomannose-type oligosaccharide (24Zamze S. Wooten E. Ashford D. Ferguson M. Dwek R. Rademacher T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 187: 657-663Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar), and it is possible that the oligosaccharide mediates an interaction between the two domains. However, this cannot be applicable to the many type 1 VSGs that do not contain an N-linked glycosylation site in the linker between the two domains. The Type 1 C1 Domain from ILTat1.24 Is Similar to the Type 2 C-terminal Domain from MITat1.2Comparison of the structure of the type 2 C-terminal domain of VSG MITat1.2 and that of the first domain of the type 1 di-domain of ILTat1.24 (Fig. 2B) shows that the overall fold is conserved. Both form a compact domain comprising two α- or 310-helices and an antiparallel β-sheet. The core structure is held together by the formation of two disulfide bonds in a CysI-III and CysII-IV pattern in both structures. A second conserved feature is the presence of two hydrophobic residues that flank the disulfide bonds. The major difference between the two structures is the C-terminal α-helix present in the type 2 domain, which is absent in the type 1 domain (Fig. 2). Comparison of VSG Type 1 C1 with Type 2 DomainsA sequence alignment was used to determine whether there is a systematic difference between C1 domains from type 1 VSGs and type 2 VSGs (Fig. 4A). The alignment was based on the cysteine residues that are in conserved locations in the structure and the number of residues between cysteines in any one VSG sequence reflected the size of secondary structure elements and/or connecting loops present. For example, there are fewer residues between CysI and CysII and between CysII and CysIII in MITat1.2C than in I1.24C1, and the two N-terminal α-helices are shorter in MITat1.2C than in I1.24C1. The

Daxx, a death domain-associated protein, is implicated in ischemic cell death. To clarify the mechanism of cell death mediated by Daxx, a yeast two-hybrid assay was performed. Sodium hydrogen exchanger isoform 1 (NHE1) was identified as a Daxx-interacting protein. During ischemic stress, Daxx translocates from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, where it colocalizes with NHE1. Daxx binds to the ezrin/radixin/moesin-interacting domain of NHE1, in competition with ezrin. Consistent with this finding, transfection of the constitutively cytoplasmic mutant, Daxx(W621A), inhibited ezrin-mediated Akt-1 activation. Moreover, transfection of Daxx(W621A), but not the Daxx(S667A) mutant that is confined to the nucleus, accelerated pHi recovery from an acid load, indicating that the cytoplasmic protein activates NHE1. Based on the results, we propose that ischemic insult triggers the nucleocytoplasmic translocation of Daxx, following which cytoplasmic Daxx stimulates the NHE1 transporter activity and suppresses activation of the NHE1-ezrin-Akt-1 pathway. Our data support a novel molecular function of Daxx as an upstream regulator of NHE1 in ischemic cell death.

Cytidine 5′-triphosphate synthase catalyzes the ATP-dependent formation of CTP from UTP using either NH3 or l-glutamine (Gln) as the source of nitrogen. GTP acts as an allosteric effector promoting Gln hydrolysis but inhibiting Gln-dependent CTP formation at concentrations of >0.15 mm and NH3-dependent CTP formation at all concentrations. A structure-activity study using a variety of GTP and guanosine analogues revealed that only a few GTP analogues were capable of activating Gln-dependent CTP formation to varying degrees: GTP ≈ 6-thio-GTP > ITP ≈ guanosine 5′-tetraphosphate > O6-methyl-GTP > 2′-deoxy-GTP. No activation was observed with guanosine, GMP, GDP, 2′,3′-dideoxy-GTP, acycloguanosine, and acycloguanosine monophosphate, indicating that the 5′-triphosphate, 2′-OH, and 3′-OH are required for full activation. The 2-NH2 group plays an important role in binding recognition, whereas substituents at the 6-position play an important role in activation. The presence of a 6-NH2 group obviates activation, consistent with the inability of ATP to substitute for GTP. Nucleotide and nucleoside analogues of GTP and guanosine, respectively, all inhibited NH3- and Gln-dependent CTP formation (often in a cooperative manner) to a similar extent (IC50 ≈ 0.2-0.5 mm). This inhibition appeared to be due solely to the purine base and was relatively insensitive to the identity of the purine with the exception of inosine, ITP, and adenosine (IC50 ≈ 4-12 mm). 8-Oxoguanosine was the best inhibitor identified (IC50 = 80 μm). Our findings suggest that modifying 2-aminopurine or 2-aminopurine riboside may serve as an effective strategy for developing cytidine 5′-triphosphate synthase inhibitors. EC 6.3.4.2; UTP:ammonia ligase (ADP-forming)) catalyzes the ATP-dependent formation of CTP from UTP using either l-glutamine (Gln) or NH3 as the nitrogen source (Scheme 1) (1Koshland Jr., D.E. Levitzki A. Boyer P.D. The Enzymes. Academic Press, Inc., New York1974: 539-559Google Scholar, 2Long C. Koshland Jr., D.E. Methods Enzymol. 1978; 51: 79-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). This glutamine amidotransferase is a single polypeptide chain consisting of two domains. The C-terminal Gln amide transfer domain catalyzes the hydrolysis of Gln. The nascent NH3 derived from this glutaminase activity is transferred via an NH3 tunnel (3Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 6447-6463Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar) to the N-terminal synthase domain, where it reacts with UTP that has been activated by ATP-dependent phosphorylation at the 4-position (4Weng M. The de novo biosynthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides is highly regulated in E. coli, and consequently, CTPS is regulated in a complex fashion (1Koshland Jr., D.E. Levitzki A. Boyer P.D. The Enzymes. Academic Press, Inc., New York1974: 539-559Google Scholar). GTP is required as a positive allosteric effector to increase the efficiency (kcat/Km) of Gln-dependent CTP synthesis (10Levitzki A. Koshland Jr., D.E. Biochemistry. 1972; 11: 241-246Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar) by stabilizing the enzyme conformation that binds the tetrahedral intermediates formed during Gln hydrolysis (11Bearne S.L. Hekmat O. MacDonnell J.E. Biochem. J. 2001; 356: 223-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). CTPS is inhibited by the product CTP (12Long C.W. Pardee A.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 4715-4721Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and displays positive cooperativity for ATP and UTP (12Long C.W. Pardee A.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 4715-4721Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Levitzki A. Koshland Jr., D.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1969; 62: 1121-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (350) Google Scholar, 14Levitzki A. Koshland Jr., D.E. Biochemistry. 1972; 11: 247-253Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). ATP and UTP act synergistically to promote tetramerization of the enzyme to its active form (14Levitzki A. Koshland Jr., D.E. Biochemistry. 1972; 11: 247-253Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). Kinetic studies on CTPS from Lactococcus lactis have suggested that the 4-phosphorylated UTP intermediate acts as a co-activator with GTP to stimulate Gln hydrolysis (15Willemoës M. Sigurskjold B.W. Eur. J. Biochem. 2002; 269: 4772-4779Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). In addition to these noncovalent modes of regulation, the yeast enzyme encoded by the URA7 gene (16Park T.S. Ostrander D.B. Pappas A. Carman G.M. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 8839-8848Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 17Park T.S. O'Brien D.J. Carman G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 20785-20794Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) and the human enzyme (18Han G.S. Sreenivas A. Choi M.G. Chang Y.F. Martin S.S. Baldwin E.P. Carman G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 38328-38336Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 19Chang Y.F. Martin S.S. Baldwin E.P. Carman G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2007; 282: 17613-17622Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 20Choi M.G. Carman G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2007; 282: 5367-5377Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar, 21Higgins M.J. Graves P.R. Graves L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2007; 282: 29493-29503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar) are regulated by phosphorylation. Recently, we reported that GTP not only activates the glutaminase activity of CTPS, but, at concentrations of >0.15 mm, it inhibits Gln-dependent CTP formation (22MacDonnell J.E. Lunn F.A. Bearne S.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2004; 1699: 213-220Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). In addition, GTP inhibits NH3-dependent CTP formation at all concentrations. The detailed mechanism by which GTP induces the conformational changes to activate the glutaminase activity and inhibit NH3-dependent CTP formation remains unknown despite the recent solution of the structures of apo-E. coli CTPS (no nucleotides bound) (3Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 6447-6463Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar), E. coli CTPS with bound CTP and ADP (9Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2005; 44: 13491-13499Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), and Thermus thermophilus CTPS with bound glutamine (23Goto M. Omi R. Nakagawa N. Miyahara I. Hirotsu K. Structure. 2004; 12: 1413-1423Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). Although Baldwin and co-workers (3Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 6447-6463Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar) crystallized E. coli CTPS in the presence of GTP, no GTP was bound in the crystalline enzyme. Modeling studies by Baldwin and co-workers (3Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 6447-6463Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar) indicate that GTP binds in a cleft located adjacent to the entrance to the glutaminase site, formed by residues 50-55, 297-301, 353-356, 438-441, 468, and 470. Replacement of Gly351 by proline in E. coli CTPS abolishes Gln-dependent CTP formation but has little effect on NH3-dependent CTP formation (5Weng M.L. Zalkin H. J. Bacteriol. 1987; 169: 3023-3028Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Mutational analysis of the residues Arg359 and Gly360 (Arg356 and Gly357 in E. coli) that reside near the oxyanion hole of L. lactis CTPS suggests that these residues play a role in binding GTP and mediate the allosteric effects of GTP on the glutaminase activity (24Willemoës M. Mølgaard A. Johansson E. Martinussen J. FEBS J. 2005; 272: 856-864Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). These observations are consistent with GTP binding at the site identified by Baldwin and co-workers (3Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 6447-6463Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). However, mutational analyses have also revealed that residues 105-110 located on the L4 loop of a symmetrically related subunit play a role in GTP-dependent activation (25Iyengar A. Bearne S.L. Biochem. J. 2003; 369: 497-507Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 26Lunn F.A. Bearne S.L. Eur. J. Biochem. 2004; 271: 4204-4212Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Surprisingly, these residues do not interact with GTP in the model, suggesting that the conformation of the enzyme observed in the crystal structure is altered upon GTP binding (Fig. 1). In addition, Arg429 (and possibly Lys432) in E. coli CTPS (27Simard D. Hewitt K.A. Lunn F. Iyengar A. Bearne S.L. Eur. J. Biochem. 2003; 270: 2195-2206Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar) and Thr431 and Arg433 in L. lactis CTPS (Thr438 and Arg440 in E. coli) (28Willemoës M. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 9407-9411Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) play a role in both GTP binding and GTP-dependent activation of the glutaminase activity. These residues reside on a mobile loop that is not fully visible in the crystal structure of E. coli CTPS. Hence, the precise interactions between CTPS and GTP remain unknown, thereby precluding detailed modeling studies. Because of the absence of detailed crystallographic structural information on the effects of the interaction of GTP with CTPS, we have used a series of guanosine and GTP analogues to determine the structural features that are required for activation and inhibition of E. coli CTPS. We show that the 5′-triphosphate, 2′-OH, and 3′-OH are required for activation but not inhibition. The 2-NH2 group of GTP plays an important role in binding recognition, whereas substituents at the 6-position play an important role in activation. The presence of a 6-NH2 group obviates activation, consistent with the inability of ATP to activate the glutaminase activity of CTPS. Our structure-activity study suggests that inhibitors targeting GTP-dependent activation of CTPS need only be derivatives of 2-aminopurine and that the ribose and 5′-triphosphate groups are not required for effective inhibition. General—Acycloguanosine monophosphate (ACVMP; Toronto Research Chemicals, North York, Canada), 2-aminopurine riboside (2-NH2-PR; Berry and Associates, Dexter, MI), 2-aminopurine riboside 5′-triphosphate (2-NH2-PRTP; IBA BioTAGnology, St. Louis, MO), 2,6-diaminopurine riboside (2-NH2-A; Berry and Associates), 2-NH2-ATP (TriLink Bio-Technologies, San Diego, CA), xanthosine 5′-triphosphate (XTP; Medicorp Inc. Montréal, Canada), 8-oxoguanosine (8-oxo-G; Berry and Associates), 8-oxoguanosine 5′-triphosphate (8-oxo-GTP; Medicorp Inc.), S6-methylguanosine 5′-triphosphate (S6-Me-GTP, Medicorp Inc.), 6-thioguanosine 5′-triphosphate (6-thio-GTP; Medicorp Inc.), 7-deazaguanosine (7-deaza-G; Berry and Associates), 7-deazaguanosine 5′-triphosphate (7-deaza-GTP; TriLink), O6-methylguanosine (O6-Me-G; Berry and Associates), O6-methylguanosine 5′-triphosphate (O6-Me-GTP; TriLink), N7-methylguanosine (N7-Me-G; Sigma), N7-methylguanosine 5′-triphosphate (N7-Me-GTP; Sigma), and 6-thioguanosine (6-thio-G; Fisher) were purchased from the indicated suppliers. Unless stated otherwise, all other chemicals were purchased form Sigma. His·Bind resin and thrombin cleavage capture kits were purchased from Novagen, Inc. (Madison, WI). Expression and Purification of CTPS—Recombinant wild-type CTPS was overexpressed and purified from E. coli strain BL21(DE3) cells containing the pET15b-CTPS1 plasmid as described previously (11Bearne S.L. Hekmat O. MacDonnell J.E. Biochem. J. 2001; 356: 223-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). This plasmid encodes wild-type E. coli CTPS bearing an N-terminal hexahistidine tag (MGSSHHHHHHSSGLVPR ↓ GSHMLEM1... CTPS). The soluble histidine-tagged CTPS was purified using metal ion affinity chromatography, and the histidine tag was subsequently removed using thrombin-catalyzed cleavage (new N-terminus, GSHMLEM1..., where M1 represents the first residue of the wild-type enzyme). The results of purification and cleavage procedures were routinely monitored using SDS-PAGE. Typically, enzyme preparations were ≥98% pure. Enzyme Assays and Protein Determinations—CTPS activity was determined at 37 °C using a continuous spectrophotometric assay by following the rate of increase in absorbance at 291 nm due to the conversion of UTP to CTP (Δϵ = 1338 m-1 cm-1) (12Long C.W. Pardee A.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 4715-4721Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The standard assay mixture consisted of Hepes buffer (70 mm, pH 8.0) containing EGTA (0.5 mm), MgCl2 (10 mm), CTPS (20-80 μg/ml), and saturating concentrations of UTP (1 mm) and ATP (1 mm) in a total volume of 1.0 ml. Enzyme and nucleotides were preincubated together for 2.5 min at 37 °C, and then the reaction was initiated by the addition of either NH4Cl or Gln. GtetraP, 2′-dGTP, ddGTP, ACVMP, 2-NH2-PRTP, 6-thio-GTP, 2-NH2-ATP, N7-Me-GTP, 8-oxo-GTP, 7-deaza-GP, and O6-Me-GTP were kept on ice prior to addition to the assay solution. The concentrations of nucleosides and nucleotides were estimated spectrophotometrically using their molar extinction coefficients (see Table 1S). The effects of varying concentrations of guanosine (0-0.5 mm) and O6-Me-G (0-0.3 mm) on Gln-dependent CTP formation were examined using fixed concentrations of Gln (0.30, 0.75, 2.50, and 10.0 mm). The effects of varying concentrations of guanosine (0-0.6 mm), GMP (0-0.6 mm), GDP (0-0.6 mm), GTP (0-1.0 mm), ITP (0-8.0 mm), and ACV (0-0.6 mm) on NH3-dependent CTP formation were examined using fixed concentrations of NH4Cl (25, 50, 100, and 150 mm). The [NH3] present at pH 8.0 was calculated using a pKa (NH4+) of 9.24 (41Jencks W.P. Regenstein J. Sober H.A. Handbook of Biochemistry. The Chemical Rubber Co., Cleveland, OH1968: J-165Google Scholar) (i.e. [NH3] = 0.0544·[NH4Cl]total). The ionic strength was maintained at 0.3 m in all assays by the addition of KCl. The observed sigmoid dependence of the relative velocities (vi/vo) on the concentration of the guanosine or corresponding nucleotides was analyzed by fitting the data to Equation 1 using nonlinear regression analysis. In Equation 1, vi and vo are the initial velocities in the presence and absence of the inhibitor, [I] is the concentration of the inhibitor, n is the Hill number, and IC50 is the concentration of inhibitor that yields 50% inhibition (42Loftfield R.B. Data Analysis—Kinetic parameters were determined by fitting initial rate kinetic data to the appropriate equations by nonlinear regression analysis using the program KaleidaGraph version 3.5 from Synergy Software (Reading, PA). Values of ko and kact (per subunit) were calculated for CTPS with the hexahistidine tag removed using a molecular mass of 61,029 Da. Reported errors on all kinetic constants and IC50 values are the S.D. values from triplicate determinations. Both purine (ATP and GTP) and pyrimidine (UTP and CTP) nucleotides are ligands for CTPS, and the ability of CTPS to utilize these different nucleotides for unique roles implies that the enzyme is able to discriminate effectively among them at the molecular level. For example, the enzyme has two overlapping binding sites for UTP and CTP (9Endrizzi J.A. Kim H. Anderson P.M. Baldwin E.P. Biochemistry. 2005; 44: 13491-13499Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Chem. 1996; 271: 15393-15400Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar) through clustered CTPS gene mutations altering residues in the CTP-binding site while retaining the ability of CTPS to bind UTP and catalyze CTP formation. Consequently, designing drugs targeted at CTPS based solely on the structure of CTP or UTP may not be an effective strategy. An alternative strategy is to block GTP-dependent activation.
